CATALYSIS A:GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 155 (1997) 179-194 Deactivation of Ni/SiO2/A1203-catalyst in hydrogenation of 3-hydroxypropanal solution Xiao Da Zhu, Hanns Hofmann Institute of Technical Chemistry 1, Friedrich-Alexander-University Erlangen-Niirnberg, Egerlandstrasse 3, D-91058 Erlangen, Germany Received 13 July 1996; received in revised form 18 November 1996; accepted 18 November 1996 Abstract The deactivation of Ni/SiO2/A1203-catalyst pellets in hydrogenation of 3-hydroxypropanal (HPA) to 1,3-propanediol (PD) was investigated in a continuously operated spinning basket reactor at temperatures 45-80 and pressures 2.60-5.15 MPa. The adsorption of by-products and probably also impurities from the liquid feed causes a deactivation of the catalyst by blockage of the mesopores of the catalyst pellets. For the description of the deactivation a reasonable mathematical model was developed. The model parameters were estimated by a method that does not require the activity of the fresh catalyst. Keywords: Deactivation; Modelling; Parameter estimation; Kinetics; Hydrogenation; Nickel catalyst; 3- hydroxypropanal; 1,3-propanediol 1. Introduction The catalytic hydrogenation of 3-hydroxypropanal (HPA) formed by the hydra- tion of acrolein (Ac) is an important process for the production of 1,3-propanediol (PD), a potentially attractive intermediate for many applications [1-3]. However, compared to butanediol, propanediol production costs are relatively high, limiting its marketing [3]. In recent years many attempts have been made (new techno- logies, highly effective catalysts) to solve this problem [1,2,4]. A high degree of conversion of HPA and a high selectivity to PD can be obtained in hydrogenation of aqueous HPA solution over a Ni/SiO~/A1203-catalyst [5-8]. Carried out in trickle beds, this process has lower production costs compared to those in slurry reactors, * Corresponding author. 0926-860X/97/$17.00 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S09 26-860X(96)00394- 8 180 X. Da Zhu, H. Hofmann/Applied Catalysis A: General 155 (1997) 179-194 however, the deactivation of the Ni/SiO2/Al203-catalyst at usual conditions cannot be neglected in long operation periods. For the prediction and prolongation of catalyst lifetime in trickle beds, the hydrogenation of HPA over the Ni/SiO2/AlzO3- catalyst pellets was investigated in a continuously operated spinning basket autoclave to avoid the problem of catalyst particle suspension. 2. Experimental 2.1. Equipment set-up The experimental set-up is shown in Fig. 1. Main part is a 2 1 autoclave R with a spinning basket fixed on the stirrer shaft 1 cm above a four-blade turbine impeller driven by a variable speed motor M. 2.2. Materials Cylindrical catalyst pellets (diameter 0.8 mm, mean length 5 ram) were supplied by Stid-Chemie AG. Their physical and chemical properties are given in literature [5,6]. A pretreatment of the catalyst was not necessary because nickel has been supplied in a reduced state with a good protection against oxidation. 16 wt% aqueous solution of HPA (available from industry) was used to prepare different concentrations of HPA in the liquid feed by dilution. Its composition is reported in literature [5]. 99.99 wt% hydrogen was supplied by Linde AG. 2.3. Experimental procedure In an experiment 20 g dry catalyst pellets were filled in the basket. 1.6 1 aqueous solution of HPA was charged into the autoclave and the whole set-up was flushed with nitrogen. Then the autoclave and its content were heated to the desired temperature while stirring under nitrogen; simultaneously liquid feed was pumped into the reactor, the pressure control system, PIC, was switched on and the exit valve of the autoclave was opened. The liquid flowed continuously from the autoclave into tank B 1 and then B2. A pressure controller (PIC) could control the liquid level in the autoclave in a range less than 5%. Finally the autoclave was purged without agitation with hydrogen, than pressurized to the desired level. After the first sample was taken, agitation was started again together with a record of the operation conditions. The liquid product in tank B2 was continuously discharged to tank B4. Hydrogenation was carried out at constant temperature (TIC) and pressure (PIC). The liquid flow rate was measured by the weight change of liquid in tank B3 per minute. It could be varied by changing the reciprocating length of pump E Samples were taken in a certain interval after purging the sample tube. Each liquid sample was analysed by gas chromatography (DANI 8521-A with FID X. Da Zhu, H. Hofmann/Applied Catalysis A: General 155 (1997) 179-194 o r I I p I 181 182 X. Da Zhu, ILL Hofmann/Applied Catalysis A: General 155 (1997) 179-194 651.1). The concentration of nickel in the catalyst pellets was determined at the start and also at the end of each experiment by AAS (Perkin-Elmer model 2100). Surface areas and pore radius distribution of catalyst pellets were measured by nitrogen adsorption (Micromeritics model 2100D). 3. Results and discussions 3.1. Experimental results The measured concentrations at different conditions are plotted versus the normalized operation time t/~-o to display the deactivation of the catalyst. Without any reaction the output concentration of a continuously operated CSTR is approximately equal to that of the input if the operation time is three times greater than the mean residence time To; the range t/To<3 is called transient regime. In case of a reacting system, product concentrations will increase and reactant concentra- tions will decrease in this regime up to the stationary level. At stationary state (in Fig. 2(A)) on the right of the vertical line t/'ro=3) the output of products per minute is equal to their rate of formation and reactant and product concentrations would remain constant if the catalyst did not deactivate. A decrease in product con- centrations at stationary state indicates a deactivation of catalyst. Fig. 2(A) shows typical concentration-time curves of HPA and PD during the hydrogenation. PD concentration at different conditions shown in Fig. 2(A)-(D) decrease with the operation time at stationary state. Therefore, the Ni/SiOz/AlzO3-catalyst pellets were evidently deactivated in HPA hydrogenation. The effect of hydrogen pressure on catalyst deactivation is presented in Fig. 2(B). As the concentration-time curves at 4.0 and 5.15 MPa almost coincide, the deactivation is independent of the hydrogen concentration in the liquid phase. Elevated temperature causes a faster decrease of PD concentration at the stationary regime (Fig. 2(C)), i.e. the catalyst loses its activity at high temperature quicker than at low temperature. By comparing the experimental results obtained with HPA solutions diluted with different amounts of deionized water, it was expected to investigate whether impurities in the feed affect the deactivationFig. 2(D) shows that the slope of the concentration-time curve at CHPA,0=2.2 mol/1 and Lm=0.894 kg/h does not differ significantly from that at CHPA,0----1.1 tool/1 and Lm-----1.195 kg/h. This may be because either some impurities in the liquid feed (even they are poisons to nickel catalysts according to the literature) have no effect on the deactivation of the used catalyst pellets, or impurities found in the feed existed already in the deionized water used for the dilution. A flatter concentration-time curve appears at higher liquid flow rate, although the concentration of impurities accumulated in the autoclave may have increased. So the deactivation of the catalyst pellets will be stronger at low liquid flow rate. X. Da Zhu, H. Hofmann/Applied Catalysis A: General 155 (1997) 179-194 183 1.50 c. To explain the above results the reaction schema and the reasons of deactivation of Ni/SiOz/A1203-catalyst pellets were investigated. 3.2. Reaction schema The hydrogenation of aqueous solution of HPA over Ni/SiOz/AleO3-catalyst powder is a three-phase reaction [5,6]. The main reaction (a) HPA+ H2 ~ PD 184 X. Da Zhu, H. Hofrnann/Applied Catalysis A: General 155 (1997) 179-194 is occurring only in the presence of catalysts. The following side reactions will also take place in hydrogenation of HPA solution. (b) HPA + PD --+ acetal + H20 (c) HPA *--, Ac + H20 (d) HPA + Ac -+ 4-oxa-1, 7-heptandial Side reaction (b) is a heterogeneous catalytic reaction. The reversible dehydration of HPA to Ac and the irreversible reaction between HPA and Ac occur only in the liquid phase [5-8]. 3.3. Reasons for deactivation of Ni/SiO2/A120~-catalyst pellets Deactivation of nickel catalysts has been investigated during the last decade, mostly in gas-solid reaction systems [9-14,16]. Loss of active sites by sintering, dissolving of nickel in the liquid phase, evaporation of nickel into the gas phase and geometrical blocking as well as adsorption of poisons are possible reasons for the deactivation. Common poisons in hydrogenation are compounds of S, Se, Te, R As, Zn, Hg, halides, Pb, NH3, C2H2Nickel can also be oxidized by oxygen to nickel oxide that has less activity in hydrogenation. Therefore, also oxygen can act as poison for nickel catalysts. Since the aqueous solution of HPA was hydrogenated at temperatures less than 80, sintering of the nickel particles on the surface of the catalyst pellet can be excluded as a reason for the deactivation; it starts normally only at temperatures higher than 200. But a loss of nickel from the catalyst pellets occurred during the hydrogenation. Table 1 shows that the nickel content in catalyst pellets decreased from 49.1% at the start of the hydrogenation to approximately 42% at the end of different experiments, depending weakly on the reaction conditions. In this case nickel was found in the liquid. If the loss of active sites of the catalysts were primarily caused by this dissolution of nickel, the activity of the catalyst would have decreased linearly with time on stream [5]. The effect of temperature on catalyst activity, mentioned above, gives further evidence. The rate of nickel dissolution is proportional to the difference between the solubility of nickel and its effective concentration in the liquid phase. As the solubility of nickel in the CO2-H20 system (most similar to the aqueous solution of HPA) decreases with increasing temperature [15], also the rate of dissolution should be faster at lower than at higher temperature, leading to a quicker deactivation of the catalyst at lower temperatures. But this could not be verified experimentally. Evidently, the small amount of surface atoms of the nickel layer dissolved, seems not to reduce the catalytically active area of the nickel surface, because the role of dissolved nickel atoms is taken over by newly exposed nickel atoms underneath, i.e. the dissolution of nickel atoms must not really cause a loss of active sites on the catalyst pellets. The specific area (SBET, Smicro and Smeso) the mean pore radius (rmicro and rmeso) and the pore distribution of fresh and deactivated catalyst were measured (see Table 2 and Fig. 3). The specific area SBET and Smicro, the mean micropore radius rmicro and the distribution of the micropores of catalyst pellets do not vary significantly during the deactivation. However, the mesopore radius rrneso, the specific area Smeso and the mesopore radius distribution of fresh catalyst pellets are somewhat different from those of the deactivated catalyst. This indicates that some mesopores of the catalyst seem to be blocked by the formation of higher molecular by-products as they can cause the blockage of mesopores, but not of micropores. Traces of S, R As, halides, Pb, NH3 were detected in the deionized water used for the dilution of the aqueous HPA solution. They are known as poisons for nickel catalysts. Therefore, a reversible and/or irreversible adsorption of such compounds could occur in HPA-hydrogenation, reducing the number of active sites. As the concentration of those poisons could not be reduced by the dilution of the original HPA solution, it cannot be excluded definitely by our experiments that these poisons contribute also to the deactivation. The rate of deactivation becomes much slower in a long duration experiment. It does not however decrease to zero. This cannot be explained by a reversible adsorption. The effect of the liquid flow rate on the catalyst activity may also be explained by a blockage of mesopores of catalyst pellets. At high liquid flow rates, correspond- ing to a short residence time, the conversion of by-products is small, and the time for an irreversible adsorption of poisons is short, i.e. the catalyst should deactivate slower. Taking into account all these observations it is believed that pore blockage by higher molecular species may be the main reason for the deactivation of Ni/SiO2/A1203-catalyst pellets. 4. Conclusions Deactivation of Ni/SiO2/A1203-catalyst pellets in hydrogenation of aqueous solution of HPA was observed as the catalyst pellets were set on stream for a long time. 60% of the activity of the catalyst was lost in a time-on-stream of 25 h at 60. The reasons for the loss of active sites seem to be the adsorption of by- products and probably also some poisons as well as the blockage of mesopores by by-products. The limited amount of nickel dissolved from catalyst particles cannot be responsible for the effective deactivation of the catalysts. A reasonable model was developed to describe the hydrogenation of HPA over Ni/SiOz/A1203-catalyst pellets with the consideration of deactivation and intra- particle diffusion. Provided intrinsic kinetics and effective diffusion coefficients are available the same method can be applied to other reaction systems with catalyst deactivation. Furthermore a new method was developed to determine the model parameters for catalyst deactivation. This method gives more reliable parameters than previous extrapolation methods, which are not applicable even for reaction systems with long transition regime. Using the estimated parameters a reasonable prediction of deactivation in hydrogenation of HPA over Ni/SiOz/AlzO3-catalyst pellets was obtained. How- ever, the model of deactivation kinetics, i.e. Eq. (1), is essentially empiric. 6. The deactivation of Ni/SiO2/Al2O3-catalyst pellets in hydrogenation of 3-hydroxypropanal (HPA) to 1,3-propanediol (PD) was investigated in a continuously operated spinning basket reactor at temperatures 45–80°C and pressures 2.60–5.15 MPa. The adsorption of by-products and probably also impurities from the liquid feed causes a deactivation of the catalyst by blockage of the mesopores of the catalyst pellets. For the description of the deactivation a reasonable mathematical model was developed. The model parameters were estimated by a method that does not require the activity of the fresh catalyst.
